McDonald's Corporation (NYSE: MCD) is one of the world's largest fast food restaurant chain, serving more than 46 million customers each day. At one time it was the largest global restaurant chain, but it has since been surpassed by multi-brand operator Yum! Brands ( which operates KFC, Taco Bell, etc.) and also by sandwich chain Subway .
It used to own the Chipotle Mexican Grill until 2006 and the Boston Market restaurant chain until 2007. Chipotle is actually very good food by today's restaurant standards. They also expanded the McDonald's menu in recent decades to include alternative meal options, such as salads and snack wraps, in order to try to capitalize on growing interest in health and wellness. Though it is clear that nothing is really"healthy"at a fast food restaurant. The concept is CHEAP and QUICK food. In order to produce enough quick, cheap food, the quality of the food is sacrificed. The movie, Food, Inc., has more information about this groing problem. These photographs and images depict quite well the real side of what McDonald's has become.
Each McDonald's restaurant is operated by a franchisee, an affiliate, or the corporation itself. The corporations' revenues come from the rent, royalties and fees paid by the franchisees, as well as sales in company-operated restaurants. McDonald's revenues grew in 2007 to $22.8 billion.
McDonald's primarily sells trash but call it food, including: hamburgers, cheeseburgers, chicken products, french fries, breakfast items, soft drinks, milkshakes, and desserts. These fast foods are all contributing to the growing obesity problem crisis in the nation and is quickly spreading across the globe. In response to obesity trends in western nations and in the face of criticism over the healthiness of its products, though it doesn't seem to be affecting sales much, the company has modified its menu to include such healthier alternatives as salads, wraps and fruit.
